H0.text: Speed and direction of the electron determine its location around the nucleus of an atom.

H1.text: Size of the electron and the neutron are the two factors that determine the location of an electron around the nucleus of an atom.

H2.text: Direction and strength of the electron are the two factors that determine the location of an electron around the nucleus of an atom.

H3.text: Energy and the attraction of the nucleus are the two factors that determine the location of an electron around the nucleus of an atom.

A4.text: In atoms with one electron (hydrogen-like atom), the energy of an orbital (and, consequently, any electron in the orbital) is determined mainly by n.

A5.text: The higher nuclear charge Z of heavier elements causes their orbitals to contract by comparison to lighter ones, so that the size of the atom remains very roughly constant, even as the number of electrons increases.
